Dr. Ames Appoints Advisers
To Dean In Control Of
Non-Athletic Activities

To Replace S.A.C.
Committee Assumes Office
July 1; To Begin Planning
With Dean In Near Future
As soon as letters of acceptance
are received this morning, announcement will be issued from the
President's office of the appointment of Robert C. Abrams, Richard
Feise, and John C. Magill as the
members of the new committee
formed to advise the Dean in the
control of non-athletic activities
next year, it was understood yesterday.
Robert Abrams will serve as the
chairman of this committee, which
was created to take the place of the
present Student Activities Council,
abolished as part of the changes ordered by the Board of Trustees recently in reforming the activities
situation on the campus.
Committee Only Advisory

This committee will serve only in
an advisory capacity, it was pointed
out by the Board, leaving direct control of all non-athletic activities in
the hands of the Dean, subject to
the approval of the President.
Abrams, who will be a senior
next year, is manager-elect of next
year's swimming squad and is a
member of the Hullabaloo staff and
of the Barnstormers.
Feise Is Active

Richard Feise, also a senior next
year, has been particularly active in
social and political work on the
campus, being president of the Liberal Club this year and recentlyelected managing editor of the
NEWS-LETTER.
The junior member of the committee will be Mr. Magill, who was
one of the sophomore managers of
football last fall, and is a member
of the Barnstormers.
The committee will officially begin its term of office on July 1, but
it will do considerable work in
making plans with the Dean before
the end of the present term.

Doyle, Lancaster,
Greenbaum To Do
Blondheim's Work

—Courtesy The Sun papers

A. C. Woods
Heads Wilmer
Eye Institute
Hopkins Graduate Will Succeed Dr. Wilmer; Appointment Effective July 1
Dr. Alan C. Woods, a graduate
of the Johns Hopkins University,
has recently accepted the appointment as acting director and professor of the Wilmer Opthalmological
Institute at the Johns Hopkins Hospital.
Dr. Woods, whose appointment
will be effective from July 1, it was
announced by President Ames, will
take the place of Dr. William H.
Wilmer, who founded the clinic in
1925, as the fulfillment of a lifelong dream. Dr. Wilmer's retirement is in accordance with the rule
of the University that professors
retire when they are 70; he will stay
with the Institute with the title of
professor emeritus.
Graduated In 1910

A tall, keen man of 45, the new
director of the clinic received his
1->achelor's degree from the Hopkins in 1910, and continued his work
in the Hopkins Medical School. He
became associate professor of the
Wilmer Institute in 1927, after an
active career which included service
in Europe during the war, when he
received the rank of major.
Since his service in the war Dr.
Woods has been associated with the
Hopkins, serving as associate pro(Continued on Page 3, Col. 2)

"Fellows, we have gathered here
this morning to raise our voices in
protest against war," the speaker
began. "I am delighted to observe
such a large attendance. This
meeting was called by the Liberal
Club, the National Student League,
and the American League Against
War and Fascism—all big names,
but don't let that worry you."
He paused for breath but got no
further. The next audible sound
to rend the chilly air was that caused
by the spat of a ripe tomato which
landed squarely on one of the antiwar posters being held aloft. Then
ensued one of the most flagrant displays of ill-breeding, rowdyism, and
childishness that it has ever been
the misfortune of the Hopkins campus to witness.
o-O-o
In a certain sense we are glad
that the meeting assumed the form
that it did—we are glad because it
offers convincing, indeed irrefutable, evidence to the Administration
that it has been unconsciously catering of late to a group of vandalistic imbeciles whose lack of knowledge is only surpassed by their disrespect for the rights of others. The
myth of the Hopkins gentleman as

As the major effort of its spring
program, the Johns Hopkins Playshop last night gave the opening performance of a play, to be presented
every evening this week but tonight,
entitled "Three Women in Love",
by Elizabeth Eager Montefiori.
Mrs. Montefiori's play is one selected out of hundreds submitted by
playwrights all over the country in
the Playshop's annual competition,
for which many well-known writers
sent manuscripts.
The play depicts the conflict between fundamentalisM and modernism in a Baptist church down South,
and is described as a serious study
of sex and religion. The plot of

Eggs Hurled at Hopkins;
Shots Fired at Alabama
Although aggressive groups at the
Hopkins throw rotten eggs when
their feelings are aroused against
other groups, at the University of
Alabama, where campus politics
have likewise flared into violence recently, guns are used. Andrew
Manning, a student from Birmingham, and a candidate for editor of
the Crimson-White, the college
newspaper, was shot in the thigh by
an unidentified assailant who demanded that Manning stop and
"talk politics."
Less than 24 hours afterward, a
masked group of students seized
Frank Muscal, whose home is in
New Jersey, whisked him fifteen
miles out of town, warned him to
withdraw from the campaign, and
then set him free.

Financial Aid
May Cease For
165 Students
Be Halted BeLack Of Adequate Appropriations

A threat of discontinuation of the
work supplied to students through
funds supplied by the Federal
Emergency Relief Administration
places the jobs of 165 students in
this University in jeopardy, it has
been announded.
Though well pleased with the successful working of the program of
relief to needy students, Harry L.
Hopkins, head of the FERA, has
stated that the cost of the project
may necessitate its cessation in
June. The government is paying
$1,000,000 monthly for this work,
which is keeping 70,726 young men
throughout the United States in
college.
Hopkins has a relief roll of 165
students, who receive $2,475 monthly, the second largest group in the
state. The largest group is at the
Maryland University, where 307
receive $4,765 monthly.

Strikes Riot Called By Sadtler
For Pacifism Dr. Lane Drenched
Heckling Begins At Outset
Of Meeting; Police Riot
Anti-War Demonstrations At
Cars Appear On Scene
Other Colleges Result In
Parades, Brawls, Arrests
Although a special meeting of the
Coming as a vehement protest
against war, Friday's strike by the
students here at Hopkins was but a
part of the nation-wide action called
at hundreds of colleges of the country by the Intercollegiate League for
Industrial Democracy and the National Student League. At numerous
Eastern colleges the scheduled
strikes came off, but these "pacifist"
demonstrations were anything but
peaceful.
In New York City, under the
Natchful eyes of police, thousands of
college and high school students
struck for an hour in a demonstration against war. There was no
violence, although police tried to
break up the demonstration on the
campus of City College, where 200
students defied ultimatums forbidding them to assemble.
In Brooklyn it was different. A
riot launched the peace drive there
on Thursday night. About 500 students of an evening high school
joined 2,000 other persons in trying to persuade 1,500 remaining students to join their ranks.
In the battle ensuing from this
"perwasion", police swung night
sticks, and demonstrators swung
fists and feet. After the turmoil was
over, eight persons were arrested,
while several police and students
were treated for minor injuries by
ambulance surgeons.
About 30 students at Massachusetts State College held an hgur's
walkout Friday.
Girls at Smith
College held an evening meeting instead, and at Vassar both students
and faculty paraded through the
streets with anti-war placards. At

Classes conducted by the late Dr.
David Blondheim have been taken
over by Dr. H. C. Lancaster, professor of French literature, Dr.
Gustav Gruenbaum, associate professor of Romance lafiguages, and
Dr. Henry Grattan Doyle, dean of
junior college of the George Washifigton University.
_
Dr. Doyle has given courses at
the Hopkins before. He was lecturer of French philology here during 1926-27, and again in 1931-32.
Nationally Known Figure

The visiting lecturer is a nationally known figure in educational circles. He was appointed professor
of Romance languages at George
Washington University in 1921.
From 1927 to 1929 he was dean of
men. In 1930, he was named dean
of the junior college.
A member of numerous educational and honorary societies, Dr.
Doyle is also connected in editbrial
capacity with many magazines and
periodicals. At the present time
he is Grand President of Pi Delta
Epsilon, national honorary college
journalism fraternity.
No successor has been appointed
to fill the vacancy caused by the
death of Dr. Blondheim.

Graduate Student's
Wife Killed In Fall
Tripping as she went up the
stairs to her fourth-floor apartment
in the St. Paul Court Apartments,
Mrs. Edward N. Hooker, wife of
a graduate student in English at the
Hopkins, fell to her death in the
stair-well by plunging nearly five
stories to the basement last Thursday evening.

Fifty Hopkins students have
signed up to attend the R. 0. T. C.
summer camps, which are to be held
from June 15 to July 26.
Thirty members of the engineering division of the Hopkins unit
will encamp at Fort Humphreys,
while twenty members of the infantry have enrolled to attend Fort
Meade, the Military Science department announced.
Army Officers In Charge

The officers to be placed in charge
of the encampments have not as
yet been appointed, but regular
army officials will be chosen. Cadet
commanders will be chosen from the
officers of the various units represented at the camps, each group being in charge of the entire encampment for a short time.
In this way each unit will receive
training in the administration of
army discipline, as well as being
subjected to it.
Students from colleges in Pennsylvania, Virginia, Maryland and the
District of Columbia will attend
the two camps.

Student Council was held Saturday
in an attempt to exactly determine
those responsible for the near-riot
which was the culmination of the
students' anti-war strike on Friday,
and to decide upon the extent of
their punishment, no definite action
has as yet been taken.
The burden of fixing the responsibility for the disrespectful attitude toward Dr. Frederic C. Lane,
associate professor in history, and
Dr. Albert E. Blumberg, instructor
in philosophy, by the students who
wished to disrupt the meeting, has
been undertaken by the council.
However, it is believed that the
members of the council are deadlocked over the question as to what
course to pursue in the case, even
though the identity of several of
the students responsible for the attack on the demonstrators is definitely known.
Called as a students' "strike
against war," the demonstration was
held in front of Levering Hall, the
speakers using the steps of the
building as a rostrum. A few minutes after 11 o'clock, when the
crowd began to gather, the first
speaker, Richard Feise, a junior and
member of the Liberal Club,
mounted the steps to make the first
address.
Immediately the trouble began.
Not attempting to listen to what
Feise or the other speakers had to
say, the hostile students remained
on the other side of the roadway in
front of Levering, and commenced
their attack during Feise's speech
with boos and catcalls.
Soon their boldness increased,
and some of them ran forward on
the road, threw their eggs and tomatoes at the assembly, and then retired.
However, few direct, hits
were scored, and the meeting continued, virtually without interruption.
It was while Dr. Lane was speaking that the fire hose was brought
into use by several students who had
sneaked around behind Levering and
entered through the rear door. The
hose was dragged through the read(Continued on Page 3, Col. 1)

Dr. Warthen Given
City Health Post
Dr. William H. F. Warthen,
graduated from the Hopkins in 1919
and from the Medical School three
years later, has been appointed Assistant Commissioner of Health in
Baltimore.
Dr. Warthen, for the last ten
years director of the Bureau of
Child Welfare, will take office on
April 24, succeeding Dr. John F.
Hempel.
The new commissioner has
worked in various hospitals, including the Hopkins, since his graduation, and is now a member of the
home economics committee of the
Baltimore Emergency Relief Committee, and has been directing the
Health Department's annual drive
against diphtheria.

Tuesday, April 17, 1934.

Hopkins Gentlemen — Phooey!

honest with themselves; they submerge whatever individuality and personality they may possess to the
almighty fetish of "being one of the boys". Among
them at the meeting were included a number of "fraternity freshmen", who by now may have formed the
impression that such a demonstration as that put on
by their seniors is justifiable and even enjoyable. We
take this occasion to enlighten them that such practices
are not in keeping with the tradition and spirit of the
Hopkins and that it is about time they begin to
develop their own thinking faculties.
Apparently—indeed, all too apparently—these
above-mentioned groups respect no one whose freedom from prejudice and consequent clearer vision
permit him to behave like a gentleman. The pleas of
Norman Heaney and Edward Sadtler for order and
fair play seemed to carry no weight whatsoever. Yet
they are the two men on the entire campus who should
have the greatest influence on student opinion. The
disregarding of all courtesy due instructors was amply
and forcefully illustrated by the disgraceful treatment
accorded Dr. Frederic C. Lane, whose remarks, by
the way, were so harmless and devoid of propaganda
as not to be out of place at a conference on preparedness. It wasn't what the speaker said that mattered
to the crowd; he was §ufficiently and irrevocably
damned simply because he dared to say anything!
This, in a country where all loyal citizens take just
pride in free speech, and at a University where "Veritas vos liberabit" is the keynote of its very existence
and mission! The entire situation seems to abound
in just such paradoxes.
o-O-o
There has been an attempt on the part of many to
justify their actions by pointing out that like outbreaks occurred in every college and university in
the East where such student anti-war strikes were
held. Therefore, they triumphantly conclude, Hopkins students have merely proved themselves human
and similar to those of other institutions. Precisely,
.and therein lies the absurdity of such reasoning.
President Ames himself has repeatedly stressed the
fact that the Hopkins owes its supremacy in the fields
of education and research to its policy of not modeling
itself upon other universities. It has attained its
present high place in the academic sun by unceasingly pursuing those principles which it considers worthy
and beneficial, irrespective of their acceptance by others. Thus, here was a golden opportunity for the
Hopkins undergraduate to establish his intelligence
and refinement by contrast—and he failed miserably.

(Continued From Page 1, Col. 3)
a universal campus figure has been exploded, temporarily at least. He still exists, yes, but is now the
exception rather than the rule ; he is the last representative of a rapidly dying species. And he has been
dispossessed by a raucous, callow, infantile type to
whom such words as propriety, decency, courtesy,
and sportsmanship are mere nothings as compared
to "the thrill of a good old egg fight," as one of the
breed so naively put it.
It serves as a challenge to the Administration that
it can no longer sit back smugly and place implicit
confidence in the Hopkins undergraduate's ability to
conduct himself like a gentleman. If this now altogether ridiculous and fictitious legend is to become a
reality once more, the Administration will find itself
compelled to awake from its lethargy and effect a
thorough housecleaning, at the same time providing
•
that no more dirt sneak in.
For what possible excuse can be found to warrant
the conduct of the vast majority of the student body
last Friday morning? Here was a small group of
their classmates seeking in a decent manner to espouse and propagate a cause which is certainly cherished by every intelligent person throughout the
world. They had purposely called their meeting during class hours because it was the only means at their
command whereby they could sufficiently emphasize
their movement and attract popular interest. No uniforms were theirs, no established course, no instrument with which they could forcibly gain the attention of the University. Spectacular methods such as
they employed were the sole effective weapons which
they possessed. And yet they did not abuse these
weapons, as the distinctly non-inflammatory content
of their speeches clearly attested to all those within
earshot.
o-O-o
As was probably to be expected, members of the
R. 0. T. C. led the bombardment of eggs, tomatoes,
and grapefruit, as well as concocting the shallowminded plan of making use of the fire hose. Here
they were, wearing the uniform of a country which
prides itself upon the common privilege of freedom
of speech, attempting to deprive others of this privilege of freedom of speech. Thoughtless fellows, they
certainly reacted to the situation in the worst possible
manner. They could have so easily turned the tide in
their own favor had one of them accepted the strikers'
invitation to speak on behalf of preparedness and the
R. 0. T. C. He would have received the enthusiastic
backing and applause of his overwhelmingly large
number of colleagues to support his assertions. And
if this ran contrary to the R. 0. T. C. policy, the
group could have manifested their disdain either by
staying away from the meeting altogether, or, if they
desired to attend, by departing entirely unimpressed
after the speeches were concluded. We were really
quite shocked by their total lack of strategy.
One other group made itself conspicuously distasteful by its asinine antics—a smaller group, yet a
more important one, since it consisted of numerous
so-called campus leaders. They also resorted to
primitive tactics to express their disapproval with the
proceedings. Two of them in particular showed that
they had not yet outgrown their swaddling-clothes
impulses—this, in spite of the fact that both are seniors, both are twenty-one years of age or more, and
both represent the Johns Hopkins in athletics. To
think that they are commonly admired by lower classmen as exemplary figures leaves us somewhat sick in
the stomach. Their names, as well as those of other
would-be luminaries, are known to the authorities.
Whether they are only too well known that, as a result,
punishment will not be meted out to them, is a matter
in which we intend to interest ourselves actively.
Then, of course, there were the inevitable satellites—the inconsequentials who blindly ape their accepted leaders, fearing that they will be doomed to
eternal contempt and ostracism if they dare to think
for themselves. They refuse to be intellectually

Kelly High Scorer
British Women Give Skillful
Performance In Exhibition
With Baltimore Girls
Continuing their winning march
toward international lacrosse honors the Blue Jays took the CrescentHamilton ten of New York into
camp, 10 to 6, but not without several hitches in their stride.
The
first three quarters produced no
spectacular lacrosse but the final
session saw the Jays put on pressure and score five much-needed
goals.
In the opening period Hopkins
had things much their own way and
scored three goals, which gave them
a false sense of security.
Kelly
opened the scoring with a goal a
few minutes after the opening whistle. Pete Reynolds' pass to Orth on
the crease gave the Jays their second marker. Lang, on a pass from
Levi, accounted for the leaders'
third goal.
Lead At Half

During the rest period the Crescents shook off their lethargy and
proceeded to outscore the Jays three
to one in the second session. Welsh
scored the first Hamilton goal but
Pasarew came right back to score
for Hopkins. Then Gould, a Half
Moon veteran, retaliated with two
goals in rapid succession.
The
Hopkins lead read four to three at
the end of the half, but the Crescents were gaining ground every
minute.
Hawkins, Crescent second defense, shot the goal that tied the
score and caused the self-certain
Jays to wake up. Fighting desperately Levi and Pasarew teamed to
put the Hopkins ten in the lead
again. At the end of the third period the Jays still possessed a onepoint lead that appeared none too
safe.
Crescents Tie Score

Coming up for the final session
the New Yorkers appeared undaunted in spirit and to prove it
Julien scored a disputed goal to
again knot the score. Awakening
to the seriousness of the issue Don
Kelly garnered the ball and after
dodging, feinting, and counterfeinting eluded his defense man and
zipped the sphere past White to
send Hopkins into the lead again.
Millard Lang relieved the Jay
rooters when he swiftly eluded his
man and added another goal to the
Jays' score. The Hamilton ten was
still fighting and Julien, Rutgers'
star of some years back, scored the
last goal for his team. Hopkins then
proceeded to score three goals. Bob
Levi, downed by two defensemen,
got up and dashed down the field
to score goal number eight for the
Jays. Don Kelly, playing in whirlwind manner, scored two goals in
the dying minutes of the battle to
assure Hopkins its hard-fought-for
victory.
The preliminary women's contest
ended in victory for the Yellows by
the score of 9 to 6. The game produced more action and thrill than
the men enthusiasts thought was
possible. The English stars, especially, showed a knowledge of the
fundamentals of the game that surprised the onlookers.

Donaldson Naylor Kelly, better
known as Don, was born September
25, 1912, in Baltimore. He began
his brilliant athletic career at
Friends School. Don starred on
the football, basketball, and lacrosse
teams in high school for four years.
He captained the lacrosse team in
his senior year and was president
of the graduating class.
As a freshman at Hopkins Kelly
was the recipient of the Eli M.
Lamb Memorial Scholarship. He
entered in 1931 and has been a
Pre-Medical student. Upon graduation this spring Don will enter
Hopkins Medical School.
11 Major Letters

Kelly is a member of the Phi
Gamma fraternity and president of
Omicron Delta Kappa.
He has earned eleven major letters in football, lacrosse, and basketball during his four years on the
campus. He was president of the
Junior Class and captain of the basketball squad in his third year. Kelly
was named on the All-Maryland
basketball squad for the past two
years and was also chosen on the
All-American lacrosse team.
Brilliant Athlete

Like other members of the present lacrosse ten, Don thinks Mt.
Washington is the team to beat
this year.
Kelly has earned a reputation as
an athlete at Hopkins that is hardly
short of remarkable. He will be
remembered in the annals of Hopkins for many years to come.

Georgetown This Week

Host Trackmen
In its second meet of the season, the Johns Hopkins track team
was nosed Out by Delaware U last
Saturday at the latter's field. The
Jays again were defeated through
laCk of ability to place in the field
events, failing to obtain one victory out of the five trials.
Jack King, Black and Blue
distance star, repeated his triumphs against Swarthmore by
capturing both the mile and half
mile runs, Sholtes and Emmert
following King to the tape.
Hopkins completed its sweep
of. the distance events by capturing first, second, and third in
the 2-mile run. Holtzman won in
the time of 11 minutes, 6.3 seconds, while Lewis and Brown,
both also representing the Black
and Blue, finished in a tie for second.
Coburn -Wins
Despite these victories, however, Hopkins was unable to
amass enough points in the remaining events to capture the
meet. The only other wins secured by the Blue Jay trackmen
were in the high and low hurdles.
The former event .was won by
Coburn, who covered the distance
in 18.2 seconds. Coburn also
gained second place in the low
hurdles, trailing Merson, of Hopkins, who won the race.
Perhaps the best showing in
the field events was made in the
discus throw, Moranek and Chancellor of the Jays finishing just a
few feet short of Carey, Delaware ace, who won the contest.

Carey proved to 'be the star of
the meet, winning the shot-put and
javelin throw as well as the discus,
and setting a new Delawaje record
4 inches in the for/
of 40 feet, 113
mer event.
Idle Next Week

The Black and Blue are idle next
week, the Junior Varsity stealing
the spotlight by facing City College
in their first meet of the season.
The Jay Vees are lacking in the
same events in which the varsity
is weak, possessing almost no material whatsoever in the field events.
Coach Hambleton urges all boys
with any ability at all to come out
for the team, as it provides an excellent stepping-stone to varsity
competition in future years.
On Thursday, April 19, the longawaited interclass meet finally
comes off. All men who wish to
participate are requested to turn
their entries in as soon as possible,
so that the officials can arrange the
A
heats in the different events.
large turnout is expected, and the
meet will be an excellent test of the
popularity of intramural sports at
Hopkins. The events:
LETTER MEN
100-yard dash, 440 yards, one and
one-half mile, 120 high hurdles,
broad jump, javelin.
SQUAD
100-yard dash, 110 yards, one
mile, 120-yard low hurdles, pole
vault, discus.
NOVICE
60-yard dash, 220-yards, 660
yards, high jump, shot-put.

Captain Bunny Brooke's netmen
opened their season with an easy 8
to 1 victory over the Gettysburg
tennis team at the latter's courts
Saturday. The Blue Jay racqueters
won all the six singles matches and
two of the doubles to account for
their points. The second doubles
team defaulted their match when
darkness and rain forced them off
the court. The Hopkins tennis team,
composed entirely of veterans of
last year, should have a winning
combine if the play in their opening
match can be taken as a criterion.
Today and Wednesday the netmen will travel to Washington and
Annapolis to encounter Georgetown
and the Navy. The same line-up
will probably be used in both tilts.
Captain Brooke, ,Ladensky, Hartman, Siverd, Blum, Palitz, Goldberg; Kramer, and Goldstein will
compose the squad.
According to advance information Navy looms as the more formidable of the two opponents,
headed by McClung and Mann,
veterans from last season.

Definite steps were taken last
Thursday towards the organization
of an informal baseball team at the
University. About twenty men attended the meeting, which was.:
called in Latrobe Hall after the regular assembly was adjourned.
It was decided at the meeting
that enough candidates were available for forming a team, and that
immediate action be taken in securing a permanent practice field. In
conjunction with this, members of
the team were sent to visit park officials and apply for the use of a diamond during the week. Steps were
also taken towards obtaining practice contests with schools in the city
in order to give the members of the
squad more experience.
Practice Daily

Practice will be held every weel
day at four o'clock, and the teani
will attempt to secure a competent
coach, if possible. It is urged that
all men with any baseball ability
come out so that the varsity team
may be selected.
Among the candidates are Hazlitt, Brown, Tinley, Carper, Byer,
All of these
Ford, and Brieter.
men have shown a great amount of
talent and bid fair to make the
varsity.

Dr. Ames Appoints Advisers
To Dean In Control Of

To Replace S.A.C.
Committee Assumes Office
July 1; To Begin Planning
With Dean In Near Future
As soon as letters of acceptance
are received this morning, announcement will be issued from the
President's office of the appointment of Robert C. Abrams, Richard
Feise, and John C. Magill as the
members of the new committee
formed to advise the Dean in the
control of non-athletic activities
next year, it was understood yesterday.
Robert Abrams will serve as the
chairman of this committee, which
was created to take the place of the
present Student Activities Council,
abolished as part of the changes ordered by the Board of Trustees recently in reforming the activities
situation on the campus.
Committee Only Advisory

This committee will serve only in
an advisory capacity, it was pointed
out by the Board, leaving direct control of all non-athletic activities in
the hands of the Dean, subject to
the approval of the President.
Abrams, who will be a senior
next year, is manager-elect of next
year's swimming squad and is a
member of the Hullabaloo staff and
of the Barnstormers.
Feise Is Active

Richard Feise, also a senior next
year, has been particularly active in
social and political work on the
campus, being president of the Liberal Club this year and recentlyelected managing editor of the
NEWS-LETTER.
The junior member of the committee will be Mr. Magill, who was
one of the sophomore managers of
football last fall, and is a member
of the Barnstormers.
The committee will officially begin its term of office on July 1, but
it will do considerable work in
making plans with the Dean before
the end of the present term.

Hopkins Graduate Will Succeed Dr. Wilmer; Appointment Effective July 1
Dr. Alan C. Woods, a graduate
of the Johns Hopkins University,
has recently accepted the appointment as acting director and professor of the Wilmer Opthalmological
Institute at the Johns Hopkins Hospital.
Dr. Woods, whose appointment
will be effective from July 1, it was
announced by President Ames, will
take the place of Dr. William H.
Wilmer, who founded the clinic in
1925, as the fulfillment of a lifelong dream. Dr. Wilmer's retirement is in accordance with the rule
of the University that professors
retire when they are 70; he will stay
with the Institute with the title of
professor emeritus.
Graduated In 1910

A tall, keen man of 45, the new
director of the clinic received his
1->achelor's degree from the Hopkins in 1910, and continued his work
in the Hopkins Medical School. He
became associate professor of the
Wilmer Institute in 1927, after an
active career which included service
in Europe during the war, when he
received the rank of major.
Since his service in the war Dr.
Woods has been associated with the
Hopkins, serving as associate pro(Continued on Page 3, Col. 2)

Eggs Hurled at Hopkins;
Shots Fired at Alabama
Although aggressive groups at the
Hopkins throw rotten eggs when
their feelings are aroused against
other groups, at the University of
Alabama, where campus politics
have likewise flared into violence recently, guns are used. Andrew
Manning, a student from Birmingham, and a candidate for editor of
the Crimson-White, the college
newspaper, was shot in the thigh by
an unidentified assailant who demanded that Manning stop and
"talk politics."
Less than 24 hours afterward, a
masked group of students seized
Frank Muscal, whose home is in
New Jersey, whisked him fifteen
miles out of town, warned him to
withdraw from the campaign, and
then set him free.

Financial Aid
May Cease For
165 Students
Be Halted BeLack Of Adequate Appropriations

A threat of discontinuation of the
work supplied to students through
funds supplied by the Federal
Emergency Relief Administration
places the jobs of 165 students in
this University in jeopardy, it has
been announded.
Though well pleased with the successful working of the program of
relief to needy students, Harry L.
Hopkins, head of the FERA, has
stated that the cost of the project
may necessitate its cessation in
June. The government is paying
$1,000,000 monthly for this work,
which is keeping 70,726 young men
throughout the United States in
college.
Hopkins has a relief roll of 165
students, who receive $2,475 monthly, the second largest group in the
state. The largest group is at the
Maryland University, where 307
receive $4,765 monthly.

Although a special meeting of the
Coming as a vehement protest
against war, Friday's strike by the
students here at Hopkins was but a
part of the nation-wide action called
at hundreds of colleges of the country by the Intercollegiate League for
Industrial Democracy and the National Student League. At numerous
Eastern colleges the scheduled
strikes came off, but these "pacifist"
demonstrations were anything but
peaceful.
In New York City, under the
Natchful eyes of police, thousands of
college and high school students
struck for an hour in a demonstration against war. There was no
violence, although police tried to
break up the demonstration on the
campus of City College, where 200
students defied ultimatums forbidding them to assemble.
In Brooklyn it was different. A
riot launched the peace drive there
on Thursday night. About 500 students of an evening high school
joined 2,000 other persons in trying to persuade 1,500 remaining students to join their ranks.
In the battle ensuing from this
"perwasion", police swung night
sticks, and demonstrators swung
fists and feet. After the turmoil was
over, eight persons were arrested,
while several police and students
were treated for minor injuries by
ambulance surgeons.
About 30 students at Massachusetts State College held an hgur's
walkout Friday.
Girls at Smith
College held an evening meeting instead, and at Vassar both students
and faculty paraded through the
streets with anti-war placards. At

Graduate Student's
Wife Killed In Fall
Tripping as she went up the
stairs to her fourth-floor apartment
in the St. Paul Court Apartments,
Mrs. Edward N. Hooker, wife of
a graduate student in English at the
Hopkins, fell to her death in the
stair-well by plunging nearly five
stories to the basement last Thursday evening.

Fifty Hopkins students have
signed up to attend the R. 0. T. C.
summer camps, which are to be held
from June 15 to July 26.
Thirty members of the engineering division of the Hopkins unit
will encamp at Fort Humphreys,
while twenty members of the infantry have enrolled to attend Fort
Meade, the Military Science department announced.
Army Officers In Charge

The officers to be placed in charge
of the encampments have not as
yet been appointed, but regular
army officials will be chosen. Cadet
commanders will be chosen from the
officers of the various units represented at the camps, each group being in charge of the entire encampment for a short time.
In this way each unit will receive
training in the administration of
army discipline, as well as being
subjected to it.
Students from colleges in Pennsylvania, Virginia, Maryland and the
District of Columbia will attend
the two camps.

Student Council was held Saturday
in an attempt to exactly determine
those responsible for the near-riot
which was the culmination of the
students' anti-war strike on Friday,
and to decide upon the extent of
their punishment, no definite action
has as yet been taken.
The burden of fixing the responsibility for the disrespectful attitude toward Dr. Frederic C. Lane,
associate professor in history, and
Dr. Albert E. Blumberg, instructor
in philosophy, by the students who
wished to disrupt the meeting, has
been undertaken by the council.
However, it is believed that the
members of the council are deadlocked over the question as to what
course to pursue in the case, even
though the identity of several of
the students responsible for the attack on the demonstrators is definitely known.
Called as a students' "strike
against war," the demonstration was
held in front of Levering Hall, the
speakers using the steps of the
building as a rostrum. A few minutes after 11 o'clock, when the
crowd began to gather, the first
speaker, Richard Feise, a junior and
member of the Liberal Club,
mounted the steps to make the first
address.
Immediately the trouble began.
Not attempting to listen to what
Feise or the other speakers had to
say, the hostile students remained
on the other side of the roadway in
front of Levering, and commenced
their attack during Feise's speech
with boos and catcalls.
Soon their boldness increased,
and some of them ran forward on
the road, threw their eggs and tomatoes at the assembly, and then retired.
However, few direct, hits
were scored, and the meeting continued, virtually without interruption.
It was while Dr. Lane was speaking that the fire hose was brought
into use by several students who had
sneaked around behind Levering and
entered through the rear door. The
hose was dragged through the read(Continued on Page 3, Col. 1)

Dr. Warthen Given
City Health Post
Dr. William H. F. Warthen,
graduated from the Hopkins in 1919
and from the Medical School three
years later, has been appointed Assistant Commissioner of Health in
Baltimore.
Dr. Warthen, for the last ten
years director of the Bureau of
Child Welfare, will take office on
April 24, succeeding Dr. John F.
Hempel.
The new commissioner has
worked in various hospitals, including the Hopkins, since his graduation, and is now a member of the
home economics committee of the
Baltimore Emergency Relief Committee, and has been directing the
Health Department's annual drive
against diphtheria.

Tuesday, April 17, 1934.

Hopkins Gentlemen — Phooey!

honest with themselves; they submerge whatever individuality and personality they may possess to the
almighty fetish of "being one of the boys". Among
them at the meeting were included a number of "fraternity freshmen", who by now may have formed the
impression that such a demonstration as that put on
by their seniors is justifiable and even enjoyable. We
take this occasion to enlighten them that such practices
are not in keeping with the tradition and spirit of the
Hopkins and that it is about time they begin to
develop their own thinking faculties.
Apparently—indeed, all too apparently—these
above-mentioned groups respect no one whose freedom from prejudice and consequent clearer vision
permit him to behave like a gentleman. The pleas of
Norman Heaney and Edward Sadtler for order and
fair play seemed to carry no weight whatsoever. Yet
they are the two men on the entire campus who should
have the greatest influence on student opinion. The
disregarding of all courtesy due instructors was amply
and forcefully illustrated by the disgraceful treatment
accorded Dr. Frederic C. Lane, whose remarks, by
the way, were so harmless and devoid of propaganda
as not to be out of place at a conference on preparedness. It wasn't what the speaker said that mattered
to the crowd; he was §ufficiently and irrevocably
damned simply because he dared to say anything!
This, in a country where all loyal citizens take just
pride in free speech, and at a University where "Veritas vos liberabit" is the keynote of its very existence
and mission! The entire situation seems to abound
in just such paradoxes.
o-O-o
There has been an attempt on the part of many to
justify their actions by pointing out that like outbreaks occurred in every college and university in
the East where such student anti-war strikes were
held. Therefore, they triumphantly conclude, Hopkins students have merely proved themselves human
and similar to those of other institutions. Precisely,
.and therein lies the absurdity of such reasoning.
President Ames himself has repeatedly stressed the
fact that the Hopkins owes its supremacy in the fields
of education and research to its policy of not modeling
itself upon other universities. It has attained its
present high place in the academic sun by unceasingly pursuing those principles which it considers worthy
and beneficial, irrespective of their acceptance by others. Thus, here was a golden opportunity for the
Hopkins undergraduate to establish his intelligence
and refinement by contrast—and he failed miserably.

(Continued From Page 1, Col. 3)
a universal campus figure has been exploded, temporarily at least. He still exists, yes, but is now the
exception rather than the rule ; he is the last representative of a rapidly dying species. And he has been
dispossessed by a raucous, callow, infantile type to
whom such words as propriety, decency, courtesy,
and sportsmanship are mere nothings as compared
to "the thrill of a good old egg fight," as one of the
breed so naively put it.
It serves as a challenge to the Administration that
it can no longer sit back smugly and place implicit
confidence in the Hopkins undergraduate's ability to
conduct himself like a gentleman. If this now altogether ridiculous and fictitious legend is to become a
reality once more, the Administration will find itself
compelled to awake from its lethargy and effect a
thorough housecleaning, at the same time providing
•
that no more dirt sneak in.
For what possible excuse can be found to warrant
the conduct of the vast majority of the student body
last Friday morning? Here was a small group of
their classmates seeking in a decent manner to espouse and propagate a cause which is certainly cherished by every intelligent person throughout the
world. They had purposely called their meeting during class hours because it was the only means at their
command whereby they could sufficiently emphasize
their movement and attract popular interest. No uniforms were theirs, no established course, no instrument with which they could forcibly gain the attention of the University. Spectacular methods such as
they employed were the sole effective weapons which
they possessed. And yet they did not abuse these
weapons, as the distinctly non-inflammatory content
of their speeches clearly attested to all those within
earshot.
o-O-o
As was probably to be expected, members of the
R. 0. T. C. led the bombardment of eggs, tomatoes,
and grapefruit, as well as concocting the shallowminded plan of making use of the fire hose. Here
they were, wearing the uniform of a country which
prides itself upon the common privilege of freedom
of speech, attempting to deprive others of this privilege of freedom of speech. Thoughtless fellows, they
certainly reacted to the situation in the worst possible
manner. They could have so easily turned the tide in
their own favor had one of them accepted the strikers'
invitation to speak on behalf of preparedness and the
R. 0. T. C. He would have received the enthusiastic
backing and applause of his overwhelmingly large
number of colleagues to support his assertions. And
if this ran contrary to the R. 0. T. C. policy, the
group could have manifested their disdain either by
staying away from the meeting altogether, or, if they
desired to attend, by departing entirely unimpressed
after the speeches were concluded. We were really
quite shocked by their total lack of strategy.
One other group made itself conspicuously distasteful by its asinine antics—a smaller group, yet a
more important one, since it consisted of numerous
so-called campus leaders. They also resorted to
primitive tactics to express their disapproval with the
proceedings. Two of them in particular showed that
they had not yet outgrown their swaddling-clothes
impulses—this, in spite of the fact that both are seniors, both are twenty-one years of age or more, and
both represent the Johns Hopkins in athletics. To
think that they are commonly admired by lower classmen as exemplary figures leaves us somewhat sick in
the stomach. Their names, as well as those of other
would-be luminaries, are known to the authorities.
Whether they are only too well known that, as a result,
punishment will not be meted out to them, is a matter
in which we intend to interest ourselves actively.
Then, of course, there were the inevitable satellites—the inconsequentials who blindly ape their accepted leaders, fearing that they will be doomed to
eternal contempt and ostracism if they dare to think
for themselves. They refuse to be intellectually

The conferences had their origin
in an institute for social progress
held last summer at Wellesley College. The organizers advocate free
speech for every phase of economics from the conservative socialist,
business, and religious viewpoints.
The committee •on arrangements
consists of A. E. 0. Munsell, Mrs.
Virginia Powell Harris, and Mrs.
Charles Sears.
Among the speakers on these programs are Drs. Broadus Mitchell
and Albert Blumberg of this University, Edwin C. Holden, Msgr.
John Ryan, Dr. Edward L. Israel,
Rev. Bruce H. McDonald, and David Cushman Coyle.
Last Saturday "The Theory of
the Leisure Class" was the topic
for discussion. The last two meetings will take up the subjects, "Business Versus Finance" and "Prohibiting Poverty."

Continuing their winning march
toward international lacrosse honors the Blue Jays took the CrescentHamilton ten of New York into
camp, 10 to 6, but not without several hitches in their stride.
The
first three quarters produced no
spectacular lacrosse but the final
session saw the Jays put on pressure and score five much-needed
goals.
In the opening period Hopkins
had things much their own way and
scored three goals, which gave them
a false sense of security.
Kelly
opened the scoring with a goal a
few minutes after the opening whistle. Pete Reynolds' pass to Orth on
the crease gave the Jays their second marker. Lang, on a pass from
Levi, accounted for the leaders'
third goal.
Lead At Half

During the rest period the Crescents shook off their lethargy and
proceeded to outscore the Jays three
to one in the second session. Welsh
scored the first Hamilton goal but
Pasarew came right back to score
for Hopkins. Then Gould, a Half
Moon veteran, retaliated with two
goals in rapid succession.
The
Hopkins lead read four to three at
the end of the half, but the Crescents were gaining ground every
minute.
Hawkins, Crescent second defense, shot the goal that tied the
score and caused the self-certain
Jays to wake up. Fighting desperately Levi and Pasarew teamed to
put the Hopkins ten in the lead
again. At the end of the third period the Jays still possessed a onepoint lead that appeared none too
safe.
Crescents Tie Score

Coming up for the final session
the New Yorkers appeared undaunted in spirit and to prove it
Julien scored a disputed goal to
again knot the score. Awakening
to the seriousness of the issue Don
Kelly garnered the ball and after
dodging, feinting, and counterfeinting eluded his defense man and
zipped the sphere past White to
send Hopkins into the lead again.
Millard Lang relieved the Jay
rooters when he swiftly eluded his
man and added another goal to the
Jays' score. The Hamilton ten was
still fighting and Julien, Rutgers'
star of some years back, scored the
last goal for his team. Hopkins then
proceeded to score three goals. Bob
Levi, downed by two defensemen,
got up and dashed down the field
to score goal number eight for the
Jays. Don Kelly, playing in whirlwind manner, scored two goals in
the dying minutes of the battle to
assure Hopkins its hard-fought-for
victory.
The preliminary women's contest
ended in victory for the Yellows by
the score of 9 to 6. The game produced more action and thrill than
the men enthusiasts thought was
possible. The English stars, especially, showed a knowledge of the
fundamentals of the game that surprised the onlookers.

Donaldson Naylor Kelly, better
known as Don, was born September
25, 1912, in Baltimore. He began
his brilliant athletic career at
Friends School. Don starred on
the football, basketball, and lacrosse
teams in high school for four years.
He captained the lacrosse team in
his senior year and was president
of the graduating class.
As a freshman at Hopkins Kelly
was the recipient of the Eli M.
Lamb Memorial Scholarship. He
entered in 1931 and has been a
Pre-Medical student. Upon graduation this spring Don will enter
Hopkins Medical School.
11 Major Letters

Kelly is a member of the Phi
Gamma fraternity and president of
Omicron Delta Kappa.
He has earned eleven major letters in football, lacrosse, and basketball during his four years on the
campus. He was president of the
Junior Class and captain of the basketball squad in his third year. Kelly
was named on the All-Maryland
basketball squad for the past two
years and was also chosen on the
All-American lacrosse team.
Brilliant Athlete

Like other members of the present lacrosse ten, Don thinks Mt.
Washington is the team to beat
this year.
Kelly has earned a reputation as
an athlete at Hopkins that is hardly
short of remarkable. He will be
remembered in the annals of Hopkins for many years to come.

Georgetown This Week

Host Trackmen
In its second meet of the season, the Johns Hopkins track team
was nosed Out by Delaware U last
Saturday at the latter's field. The
Jays again were defeated through
laCk of ability to place in the field
events, failing to obtain one victory out of the five trials.
Jack King, Black and Blue
distance star, repeated his triumphs against Swarthmore by
capturing both the mile and half
mile runs, Sholtes and Emmert
following King to the tape.
Hopkins completed its sweep
of. the distance events by capturing first, second, and third in
the 2-mile run. Holtzman won in
the time of 11 minutes, 6.3 seconds, while Lewis and Brown,
both also representing the Black
and Blue, finished in a tie for second.
Coburn -Wins
Despite these victories, however, Hopkins was unable to
amass enough points in the remaining events to capture the
meet. The only other wins secured by the Blue Jay trackmen
were in the high and low hurdles.
The former event .was won by
Coburn, who covered the distance
in 18.2 seconds. Coburn also
gained second place in the low
hurdles, trailing Merson, of Hopkins, who won the race.
Perhaps the best showing in
the field events was made in the
discus throw, Moranek and Chancellor of the Jays finishing just a
few feet short of Carey, Delaware ace, who won the contest.

Carey proved to 'be the star of
the meet, winning the shot-put and
javelin throw as well as the discus,
and setting a new Delawaje record
4 inches in the for/
of 40 feet, 113
mer event.
Idle Next Week

The Black and Blue are idle next
week, the Junior Varsity stealing
the spotlight by facing City College
in their first meet of the season.
The Jay Vees are lacking in the
same events in which the varsity
is weak, possessing almost no material whatsoever in the field events.
Coach Hambleton urges all boys
with any ability at all to come out
for the team, as it provides an excellent stepping-stone to varsity
competition in future years.
On Thursday, April 19, the longawaited interclass meet finally
comes off. All men who wish to
participate are requested to turn
their entries in as soon as possible,
so that the officials can arrange the
A
heats in the different events.
large turnout is expected, and the
meet will be an excellent test of the
popularity of intramural sports at
Hopkins. The events:
LETTER MEN
100-yard dash, 440 yards, one and
one-half mile, 120 high hurdles,
broad jump, javelin.
SQUAD
100-yard dash, 110 yards, one
mile, 120-yard low hurdles, pole
vault, discus.
NOVICE
60-yard dash, 220-yards, 660
yards, high jump, shot-put.

Captain Bunny Brooke's netmen
opened their season with an easy 8
to 1 victory over the Gettysburg
tennis team at the latter's courts
Saturday. The Blue Jay racqueters
won all the six singles matches and
two of the doubles to account for
their points. The second doubles
team defaulted their match when
darkness and rain forced them off
the court. The Hopkins tennis team,
composed entirely of veterans of
last year, should have a winning
combine if the play in their opening
match can be taken as a criterion.
Today and Wednesday the netmen will travel to Washington and
Annapolis to encounter Georgetown
and the Navy. The same line-up
will probably be used in both tilts.
Captain Brooke, ,Ladensky, Hartman, Siverd, Blum, Palitz, Goldberg; Kramer, and Goldstein will
compose the squad.
According to advance information Navy looms as the more formidable of the two opponents,
headed by McClung and Mann,
veterans from last season.
Scores of the Geftysburg singles:
Brooke, J. H. U., defeated Achey,
6-2,6 0.
Ladensky, J. H. U., defeated Dunkleberger, 6-=1, 6 0.
Hartman, J. H. U., defeated Fink,
6 1, 6-2.
Siverd, J. H. U., defeated Menhenny, 6 0, 6 0.
Blum, J. H. U., defeated Livingood,
6 1, 6 1.
Palitz, J. H. U., defeated Brazel,
6-3, 6-3.

Definite steps were taken last
Thursday towards the organization
of an informal baseball team at the
University. About twenty men attended the meeting, which was.:
called in Latrobe Hall after the regular assembly was adjourned.
It was decided at the meeting
that enough candidates were available for forming a team, and that
immediate action be taken in securing a permanent practice field. In
conjunction with this, members of
the team were sent to visit park officials and apply for the use of a diamond during the week. Steps were
also taken towards obtaining practice contests with schools in the city
in order to give the members of the
squad more experience.
Practice Daily

Practice will be held every weel
day at four o'clock, and the teani
will attempt to secure a competent
coach, if possible. It is urged that
all men with any baseball ability
come out so that the varsity team
may be selected.
Among the candidates are Hazlitt, Brown, Tinley, Carper, Byer,
All of these
Ford, and Brieter.
men have shown a great amount of
talent and bid fair to make the
varsity.
